Text: Teacher: Hi Cody, talk me through your solution|EOM|Cody: Sure. I started by figuring out how much money Billy had left to spend on candy. He had $10, and if he spent half his change on gumballs, he had $5 left to spend on candy and gumballs. He spent $0.05 x 40 = $2 on gumballs, so he had $5 - $2 = $3 left to spend on candy. Then I divided $3 by $1.5 per pound to get 2 pounds of candy. So, Billy bought 2 pounds of candy.|EOM|
Label: generic

Text: Teacher: Okay - let's revisit this by starting with how much he spent on gumballs|EOM|Cody: Sure. Billy spent $0.05 x 40 = $2 on gumballs. Then I subtracted that from the $10 his father gave him, so he had $5 - $2 = $3 left to spend on candy. Then I divided $3 by $1.5 per pound to get 2 pounds of candy. So, Billy bought 2 pounds of candy.|EOM|
Label: focus

Text: Teacher: Slow down. He spents $2 on gumballs. You need to / this by 0.5 to calculate the change|EOM|Cody: Oh, okay. Billy spent $0.05 x 40 = $2 on gumballs. Then I divided that by 0.5 to get the change, which was $2/0.5 = $4. Then I subtracted that from the $10 his father gave him, so he had $10 - $4 = $6 left to spend on candy. Then I divided $6 by $1.5 per pound to get 4 pounds of candy. So, Billy bought 4 pounds of candy.
Label: focus
